column4: i didn't know external displays on laptops would be this difficult--it flickers when I boot but doesn't load anything after that
what's the difference between "Monitor" and "Screen" in xorg.conf?
In some drivers, for example, you can have a single screen spread across multiple monitors.
A screen is a device that graphics render to, a monitor is a physical device.
I see--is there a way to easily add or change the monitor in the xorg.conf to use an external LCD instead of a laptops internal LCD?
That depends on the graphics driver - there is no easy, sure fire way. You'd have to read the specific driver's documentation.
Does your laptop not a device switch?
Or are you trying to setup dual monitor support?
I would just like to bypass the laptop's LCD completely and use the external
I'm using the ati driver
The easy solution is to use the laptop switch, then.
what is that?
The ATI proprietary or the supplied xorg one?
Most laptops have a button combination that will redirect the graphics to the external monitor port. It's usually like a Fn-<soething> command.
I believe the supplied one, it loaded automatically with the installer
I'm using a powerbook--does that matter?
Yeah, use Fn-F2.
Try that first.
during boot?
Just right now.
fn-F2 controls brightness
One of those Fns should work. Sorry that I gave the wrong one.
